summary: A Palm Beach Police Department incident report detailing a burglary at Jeffrey Epstein's residence at 358 El Brillo Way on October 5, 2003. Epstein reported $2,700 in cash and a Glock handgun stolen. Surveillance footage led to the identification of his former houseman, Juan Alessi, who later confessed and returned some of the money. The case was exceptionally cleared. This is a Palm Beach Police Department incident report detailing the investigation into a burglary and theft at Jeffrey Epstein's residence at 358 El Brillo Avenue. The report documents the confession of Juan Alessi, Epstein's former house manager, to stealing money from Epstein's briefcase on two occasions in 2003. It concludes that Epstein declined to prosecute, leading to the case being exceptionally cleared.

persons.name: Jeffrey Edward Epstein
persons.context: Reports a burglary at his Palm Beach residence, stating cash and a handgun were stolen. He set up a spy camera which captured the suspect. He later met with the suspect, Juan Alessi, who confessed.

persons.name: Juan P. Alessi
persons.context: Former employee of Epstein, identified via surveillance footage as the burglar. He confessed to breaking in to steal a gun, took money instead, and returned $2,000.

persons.name: Marie Alessi
persons.context: Wife of Juan Alessi. Police spoke with her while attempting to locate Juan.

persons.name: John Alessi
persons.context: Former house manager at Epstein's residence, employed there for approximately 10 years prior to other managers.

persons.name: Valdson Vieira Cotrin
persons.context: Live-in employee at the residence. Provided a statement that he did not see or hear anything unusual on the night of the burglary.

persons.name: Michael David Eason Friedman
persons.context: House manager at the residence. Provided a statement about his movements on the night of the incident.

persons.name: Det. Greene
persons.context: Palm Beach Police detective who led the investigation, collected evidence (including surveillance video), and interviewed the suspect.

persons.name: Juan Alessi
persons.context: Confessed to entering Jeffrey Epstein's house twice in 2003 and stealing a total of $7,500 from Epstein's briefcase. He was the former house manager from 1991 to 2002.

persons.name: Jeffrey Epstein
persons.context: The victim of the burglary and theft at his Palm Beach residence. He met with Alessi and agreed to have the stolen money repaid, and subsequently declined to prosecute.

persons.name: Officer Greene
persons.context: The police officer who authored the incident report, documenting the investigation, Alessi's confession, and Epstein's decision not to prosecute.

persons.name: Marie Ales
persons.context: Listed as an investigative contact to be added to the police system, mentioned in the report's administrative notes.

persons.name: John
persons.context: Listed as an investigative contact (last name redacted/truncated as 'ress') to be added to the police system, mentioned in the report's administrative notes.

connections.description: Epstein was the former employer of Alessi, who worked as a houseman. The relationship turned adversarial when Alessi burglarized Epstein's home.
Marie Alessi is the wife of suspect Juan Alessi, as indicated when police contacted her.
John Alessi was a former house manager for Epstein, employed for about 10 years.
Cotrin is identified as the resident chef, a live-in employee at Epstein's Palm Beach residence.
Friedman is identified as the house manager, an employee living on-site at the residence.
Alessi worked as Epstein's house manager from January 1991 to September 2002.
Alessi stole money from Epstein's briefcase, and they later met and agreed Alessi would repay the stolen funds.

events.title: Burglary at Epstein Residence
events.description: Jeffrey Epstein reports a burglary at his Palm Beach home. $2,700 in cash and a Glock 9mm handgun are stolen. Surveillance footage is later recovered.

events.title: Previous Suspected Theft (Labor Day Weekend)
events.description: Epstein suspects cash was taken from his briefcase over Labor Day weekend, but he did not report it at the time.

events.title: Previous Suspected Theft (Mid-September)
events.description: Epstein suspects cash was taken from his briefcase on a weekend in mid-September 2003, but he did not report it.

events.title: Confession and Partial Recovery
events.description: Epstein meets with Juan Alessi at Green's Pharmacy. Alessi confesses to the burglary and returns $2,000 of the stolen money. Epstein informs police.

events.title: Police Interview with Juan Alessi
events.description: Detectives make contact with Juan Alessi via his wife and cell phone. Alessi agrees to come to the police station for an interview, where he is read his Miranda rights.

events.title: First Burglary at Epstein Residence
events.description: Juan Alessi entered Jeffrey Epstein's house at 358 El Brillo Avenue through an unlocked sliding glass door and stole approximately $1,900 from Epstein's briefcase.

events.title: Meeting Between Epstein and Alessi
events.description: Jeffrey Epstein and Juan Alessi met and agreed that Alessi would repay all the money he had taken from Epstein's house.

events.title: Police Attempt to Obtain Affidavit
events.description: Officer Greene faxed an affidavit of prosecution to Epstein, requesting he formally indicate he did not wish to prosecute Alessi. Surveillance equipment was also removed from Epstein's residence.

events.title: Case Exceptionally Cleared
events.description: The Palm Beach Police Department closed the burglary and theft case as 'Exceptionally Cleared' because the suspect was identified, there was enough evidence for an arrest, but the victim (Epstein) declined to prosecute.

locations: 358 El Brillo Way, Palm Beach, FL
358 El Brillo Avenue, Palm Beach, Florida (Jeffrey Epstein's residence)
keyFacts: Jeffrey Epstein reported a burglary at his Palm Beach home on October 5, 2003, with $2,700 and a Glock 9mm handgun stolen.
Epstein had set up a spy camera which captured surveillance footage of the suspect, identified as his former houseman, Juan P. Alessi.
Juan Alessi confessed to the burglary, stating he broke in to steal a gun but took money instead. He returned $2,000 to Epstein.
The police report indicates prior unreported incidents of suspected theft from Epstein's briefcase in August and September 2003.
The case was 'exceptionally cleared' after the confession and partial recovery of funds, though the handgun remained missing.
Juan Alessi, Epstein's former house manager, confessed to burglarizing Epstein's Palm Beach home twice in October 2003 and stealing a total of $7,500.
Epstein owned a silver revolver that was kept in his office, which Alessi admitted he helped place there but denied stealing.
Epstein met with Alessi and agreed to have the stolen money repaid, after which he declined to prosecute Alessi for the burglary.
Despite having Alessi's confession on video and enough evidence for an arrest, the police case was 'Exceptionally Cleared' because Epstein, the victim, refused to prosecute.

The report indicates several failed attempts by police to get Epstein to formally complete an affidavit stating he did not wish to prosecute, though he had verbally communicated this to police leadership.
